text: Suppose that you cut a large circular pizza into 8 identical slices. You can reposition those slices to make a new shape:
• How are the circle and new shape related? If you cut the pizza into 16 or 32 pieces, how does this affect the new shape?

The new shape will look like a parallelogram. A shorter side of the new shape is equal to the radius of the circle and a longer side in is equal to half length of the perimeter of the circle. So, you can say the perimeter of the new shape is equal to the sum of the circumference of the circle and two radius (or diameter). If you cut the pizza into 16 or 32 pieces, the new shape will look closer to rectangular than a parallelogram.
• How does the area of the circle compare to the area of the shape?
Since you just re-arrange 8 pieces of pizza, the area of the new shape is same as that of the circle.
• If the radius of pizza is 6 inches, what is its circumference? Its area?
Since the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter is p (3.1415...), the circumference will be p x 12 ≈ 37.68.
• Estimate the height and base of the new shape. What is the approximate area of the shape? How does the area of the shape compare to the area of the circle?

The area of the new shape is same as the circle, which is p x 6 x 6 ≈ 113.04. If you cut the pizza into many pieces like 32, then you can see the new shape looks like a rectangle. The base of it is half of the circumference of the circle, which is 1⁄2 x p x 12 ≈1⁄2 x 37.68 ≈ 18.84. The height of it is close to and little bit less than the radius, 6. If you find the area of the new shape by multiplying the base by its height (18.84 x 6), you will get the same results as 113.04.

Note: When arranging the slices, it may not be automatic that students arrange them in a long rectangle. This is an example of students working to relate the area of a circle to an area more square-like.
